docs.abstract: Adam Sandler and Jennifer Aniston return as private detectives in this Netflix follow-up comedy.
docs.snippet: Adam Sandler and Jennifer Aniston return as private detectives in this Netflix follow-up comedy.
docs.lead_paragraph: For a certain brand of Adam Sandler films, you know what you’re going to get: something cheerfully lowbrow, easygoing and listlessly comforting when used as background programming. Such movies are what make the actor’s longstanding partnership with Netflix perhaps too suitable a match, as the bulk of the company’s original content has been gradually cheapened to a similar brand. With “Murder Mystery 2,” the sequel to the 2019 comedy “Murder Mystery,” it’s much of the same.

headline.main: ‘Murder Mystery 2’ Review: The Case of the Innocuous Sequel

docs.abstract: As South Carolina seeks its second straight N.C.A.A. women’s basketball championship, Coach Dawn Staley carries the hopes of her family, her team and the generation of coaches she has inspired.
docs.snippet: As South Carolina seeks its second straight N.C.A.A. women’s basketball championship, Coach Dawn Staley carries the hopes of her family, her team and the generation of coaches she has inspired.
docs.lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Dawn Staley greeted her players at midcourt on Monday with a pregame ritual, briefly dancing a two-step called the Baltimore Shuffle. After the South Carolina women’s basketball team dispatched Maryland to reach the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. tournament, the Gamecocks cut down the net at one basket. Staley, their coach since 2008, slipped it like jewelry over her Louis Vuitton sweatsuit. A “netlace,” she has called it through the years.

headline.main: ‘I Don’t Want to Let Them Down’
headline.print_headline: Staley Is a Dream Merchant. And Business Is Good.

docs.abstract: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, who served as an infantryman in Afghanistan before joining The Times in 2017, takes on a new role: Ukraine correspondent.
docs.snippet: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, who served as an infantryman in Afghanistan before joining The Times in 2017, takes on a new role: Ukraine correspondent.
docs.lead_paragraph: Since Russia invaded Ukraine more than a year ago, journalists at The New York Times have covered the tragedies, devastation and death tolls, as well as Ukraine’s resistance and resilience. As the war grinds on with no end in sight, The Times has created a new role for Thomas Gibbons-Neff, the former Kabul bureau chief: Ukraine correspondent.

headline.main: A Former Marine, Reporting on the Front Lines of a Different War
headline.print_headline: A Former Marine Reports on the Front Lines

docs.abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
docs.snippet: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
docs.lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

docs.abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
docs.snippet: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
docs.lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

docs.abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
docs.snippet: What do you think this image is communicating?
docs.lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

docs.abstract: Ulysses S. Grant was all but ruined by his involvement in investment banking, but unlike Donald Trump, he was never indicted.
docs.snippet: Ulysses S. Grant was all but ruined by his involvement in investment banking, but unlike Donald Trump, he was never indicted.
docs.lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at the indictment of former President Donald Trump in the context of presidential history in New York. We’ll also look at why subway token-booth clerks have stepped out of their booths.

headline.main: Once Before, an Ex-President Was in Jeopardy in New York

docs.abstract: “He was right — we’re finally saying ‘Merry Christmas’ again!” Stephen Colbert said of Donald Trump on Thursday.
docs.snippet: “He was right — we’re finally saying ‘Merry Christmas’ again!” Stephen Colbert said of Donald Trump on Thursday.
docs.lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline.main: Late Night Is Tickled by Trump’s Indictment

docs.abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

docs.lead_paragraph: The word bleat has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 19 in “Covid Stopped the Music. Now This School Is Striking Up the Band Again” by Sarah Diamond:

docs.abstract: The war in Ukraine may be a horror, but it’s also an opportunity.
docs.snippet: The war in Ukraine may be a horror, but it’s also an opportunity.
docs.lead_paragraph: From the perspective of a Russian soldier, the war in Ukraine must look nightmarish. In over a year of combat, nearly 200,000 Russian troops have been killed or wounded, according to American officials, in a military operation that has proved both incompetent and ill equipped. Morale is reportedly low and complaints common. And yet a significant number of Russian men are still keen to fight — more, in fact, than at the war’s outset. What explains the disconnect?

headline.main: Why Do Russians Still Want to Fight?

byline.original: By Marlene Laruelle and Ivan Grek
